A home equity conversion mortgage (HECM) is a type of reverse mortgage that allows seniors 62 and older to convert the equity in their homes into cash for expenses, retirement income, or home repairs.

The amount you can borrow with a home equity conversion mortgage (HECM) is based on theappraised valueof the home and is insured by theFederal Housing Administration (FHA). Unlike a traditionalmortgageloan, the money borrowed from a reverse mortgage, like an HECM, does not need to be repaid monthly.

Instead, the borrower must repay the entire loan when the home is sold or either the borrower(s) passes away or moves out of the property. In return, the borrower must pay the reverse mortgagelenderfees and interest that has accrued on the outstanding loan balance.

However, the homeowner must continue to maintain the home and pay theirproperty taxesandhomeowners' insurance. Discover how a home equity conversion mortgage (HECM) works and how to qualify.

Home equity conversion mortgages are a popular type ofreverse mortgageand make up the bulk of the reverse mortgage market.

A HECM shares similarities to ahome equityloan since borrowers have the option of receiving a cash advance based on theequity value of their home, which acts as collateral. With ahome equity loan, the homeowner must repay the funds in monthly payments shortly after the funds are disbursed.

Conversely, HECM loans do not require borrowers to make monthly payments but instead must repay the loan when the borrower sells their home or passes away. In return, the lender charges closing costs, interest, and fees for servicing the loan.

An HECM allows borrowers to receive the money in a few ways, allowing for customization. However, how you receive the funds determines whether you're charged a fixed or adjustable interest rate on the balance. Adjustable-rate loans fluctuate with market interest rates, usually based on an index, and can increase or decrease over time.

An HECM provides flexibility since it can be used for monthly retirement income, home improvements, or as a backup credit line for emergencies.

The maximum HECM loan limit in 2025, up from $1,149,825 in 2024.

Borrowers must also paymortgage insurance premiumsfor an HECM. Although these premiums and fees can be rolled into the loan, this results in a lower amount of equity that a borrower can tap into, referred to as thenet principal limit.

Reverse mortgage loans—not backed by the FHA and are privately sponsored—may have different terms than HECMs. Theseproprietary reverse mortgageloans may allow forhigher borrowing amounts with lower coststhan HECMs. However, HECMs typically offer lower interest rates for borrowers.

Whether an HECM or a privately sponsored reverse mortgage is right for you will depend on various factors, including your age and how long you plan on living in the home. Homeowners have the choice of different types of reverse mortgages, some of which allow you to remain in the home with no requirements for repayment until you sell the home or pass away.

A home equity conversion mortgage (HECM) is the most common type ofreverse mortgage. An HECM allows borrowers 62 and older to tap into their home equity without needing to repay the funds until they pass away or move out of the home.

An HECM allows borrowers to receive the funds as a lump sum upfront, monthly income installments, or a credit line that they can tap into as needed. However, there are fees, closing costs, and interest charged on the borrowed funds that reduce your home's equity.
